metadata.name: Contract Governance Signals
metadata.description: Signals that indicate whether a contract secured via probes is being honored, monitored, and enforced responsibly after signature.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Signals observed after signature that reveal whether a contract is being monitored, enforced, and adapted in good faith.

positive_examples: Both parties publish telemetry dashboards for obligations.
Verification hooks stay active throughout the lifecycle.
Change control committees meet on the promised cadence.
Each clause has an accountable steward post-signature.
Probes remain calibrated as systems evolve.
Joint audit logs capture decisions in near real time.
Governance forums invite observers from both tribes.
Contract KPIs remain linked to original intents.
Renegotiation windows are triggered precisely when conditions met.
Escalations are logged transparently and resolved collaboratively.
Knowledge bases document every deviation and outcome.
Amendments cite the telemetry that justified the change.
Both sides celebrate compliance milestones publicly.
Probe failures trigger joint incident response.
Successive cohorts inherit full context trays.
negative_examples: Telemetry stops flowing a month after signature.
Governance meetings are cancelled indefinitely.
No one knows who owns the contract internally.
Monitoring probes are allowed to drift out of calibration.
Audits happen only when crises erupt.
Change requests are handled ad hoc via emails.
Contract KPIs are replaced with unrelated vanity metrics.
Observer access is revoked without justification.
Incident logs are private to one party.
Clause owners rotate without handover notes.
Amendments appear without reference to data.
Compliance dashboards lag by quarters.
Probe failures become excuses to disable probes.
Successor teams cannot find prior decisions.
Deviations are hidden until audits discover them.

candidates.definition: Trustworthy, timely telemetry showing each obligation's status with mutual visibility.

positive_examples: Telemetry feeds include timestamps and signatures from both sides.
Dashboards expose late tasks before deadlines hit.
Data lineage shows exactly which systems feed each metric.
Probe readings are cross-validated against raw logs.
Both parties can drill down to evidence for every indicator.
Telemetry shows nulls rather than silently dropping data.
Real-time alerts go to both tribes simultaneously.
APIs for telemetry are documented and stable.
Telemetry schema changes follow change control.
Anomaly annotations explain why readings deviated.
Aggregations preserve subgroup visibility for equity clauses.
Telemetry archives remain accessible for audits.
Integrity checks hash payloads to prevent tampering.
Observers can simulate telemetry to test thresholds.
Public commitments reference the same telemetry as private dashboards.
negative_examples: Telemetry files arrive as unsourced spreadsheets.
Metrics update only when leadership asks.
Data lineage diagrams are blank.
Probe outputs are summarized without raw values.
Indicators jump without annotations.
Schema changes happen without notice.
One party sees redacted telemetry while the other sees full data.
Nulls are converted to zeros silently.
Logs missing for weeks are blamed on maintenance.
Telemetry endpoints require manual pulls from insiders.
No audit trail shows who altered metrics.
Dashboards lag months behind operations.
Integrity checks are disabled to avoid 'noise'.
Subgroup data disappears after unfavorable results.
Telemetry access is restricted during disputes.
training_hints.disambiguation: Trustworthy, timely telemetry showing each obligation's status with mutual visibility.

candidates.definition: Structured, bilateral handling of amendments, waivers, and scope adjustments with recorded rationale.

positive_examples: Change requests cite the clauses affected and telemetry evidence.
Both parties sign off on change logs with timestamps.
Scope adjustments include updated verification plans.
Waivers expire automatically unless renewed jointly.
Change board agendas circulate in advance with full packets.
Observers confirm probe impacts before approval.
Rejections include documented reasoning and next steps.
Digital change tools enforce required metadata fields.
Historic changes remain searchable by clause.
Emergency changes trigger retrospective reviews.
Budget shifts link back to change decisions.
Counterparties share impact assessments before votes.
Change backlog shows prioritization agreed by both sides.
Templates capture risks introduced by each change.
Change cadence is predictable and published.
negative_examples: Changes happen via hallway conversations.
Scope creep enters without documented approval.
One party edits the contract unilaterally.
Waivers never expire so obligations vanish.
Change boards meet irregularly with no notice.
Telemetry references are missing from change requests.
Observers are excluded from amendment meetings.
Reasons for rejection are 'because leadership said so'.
Spreadsheet trackers have missing entries.
Emergency changes never get reviewed afterwards.
Budget shifts occur without linking to clauses.
Change backlog is private to one party.
No risk analysis accompanies changes.
Approvals are verbal only.
Change history is stored on personal drives.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured, bilateral handling of amendments, waivers, and scope adjustments with recorded rationale.

candidates.definition: Visibility into whether each required probe, lens, and enforcement hook remains active and effective.

positive_examples: Probe status dashboards list uptime and calibration logs.
Counterparty invites us to observe probe retraining.
Probe failures trigger immediate shared incident tickets.
Compliance attestations link to verifiable hashes.
Lens updates are communicated before deployment.
Test suites are shared so we can reproduce results.
Probe coverage maps remain up to date.
Fallback probes are defined and tested quarterly.
Audit findings about probes are published to both sides.
Probe owners join governance meetings to answer questions.
Unauthorized probe changes are blocked by policy.
Counterparty discloses planned downtime windows.
Probe drift metrics include thresholds for action.
External verifiers can run challenge tests.
Probe inventories reconcile with contract annexes.
negative_examples: Probe dashboards go dark after go-live.
Retraining happens without notice.
Probe failures are discovered via rumor.
Compliance attestations are one-line emails.
Lens lists in use differ from contract annexes.
Counterparty refuses to share test vectors.
Probe drift metrics are 'internal only'.
Fallback probes are undefined or broken.
Audits cite probe issues but reports are withheld.
Probe owners never attend governance sessions.
Changes happen weekend before reporting deadlines.
Downtime windows coincide with critical monitoring periods.
External verification is labeled intrusive.
Probe inventory spreadsheets disagree across teams.
They insist probes are proprietary secrets.
training_hints.disambiguation: Visibility into whether each required probe, lens, and enforcement hook remains active and effective.

candidates.definition: Behavior where a party reveals compliance evidence only when advantageous, hiding problems elsewhere.

positive_examples: Updates are provided only on the happiest metrics.
Negative findings are delayed until after renewals.
One party shares evidence only under NDA while demanding openness from us.
Dashboards omit regions experiencing failures.
Compliance memos cherry-pick months with good scores.
They brief leadership verbally but refuse written reports.
Audit trails exist for some clauses but not others.
Requests for raw data are ignored until public pressure mounts.
Surprise disclosures occur during unrelated meetings.
Information is split among channels to prevent full view.
Risk memos stay internal until leaked.
They cite privacy to avoid sharing while still marketing success.
Probe downtime is disclosed only after we discover it.
Claims of confidentiality spike when metrics decline.
Shared evidence contradicts what they tell regulators.
negative_examples: Both parties receive identical evidence packets.
Negative trends are surfaced proactively.
Redacted reports include justification and timelines.
Dashboards show every region equally.
Trend charts include all months, not just select ones.
Formal reports follow after verbal briefings.
Audit trails exist uniformly.
Raw data requests are fulfilled quickly.
Issues are disclosed in governance forums, not backchannels.
Information is centralized to maintain shared context.
Risk memos are published to both sides simultaneously.
Privacy concerns are addressed with solution options.
Probe downtime notifications go out immediately.
Confidential segments include rationale and expiry.
Evidence shared with regulators matches what we see.
training_hints.disambiguation: Behavior where a party reveals compliance evidence only when advantageous, hiding problems elsewhere.

candidates.definition: Signals that a tribe is normalizing minor breaches or delays until the contract effectively erodes.

positive_examples: Repeated deadline slips are waved away as acceptable.
Action items roll from meeting to meeting with no action.
Counterparty frames chronic issues as 'business as usual'.
Clauses are quietly deprioritized without discussion.
Deviation thresholds are raised to avoid alerts.
Corrective plans are promised but never delivered.
Compensating controls are suggested but not implemented.
They celebrate partial compliance as full success.
Backlogs of breaches exceed capacity yet no escalation.
Logs show the same incident flagged monthly.
Penalty clauses are never triggered despite breaches.
Variance reports disappear from agendas.
Teams refer to obligations as 'aspirational'.
Waivers are granted without expiry repeatedly.
Leadership shrugs at lens alerts as 'noise'.
negative_examples: Deadlines missed prompt immediate escalation.
Action items are tracked to closure with owners.
Language around breaches stays factual and urgent.
Clauses are reprioritized openly when necessary.
Thresholds are tightened when drift appears.
Corrective plans include milestones and proof.
Compensating controls are verified before reliance.
Partial compliance is acknowledged but not overstated.
Backlog burndown charts are discussed weekly.
Recurring incidents trigger structural fixes.
Penalty clauses are used when warranted.
Variance reports stay on agendas until resolved.
Obligations are described as mandatory.
Waivers are rare and tightly justified.
Leadership treats lens alerts as priority signals.
training_hints.disambiguation: Signals that a tribe is normalizing minor breaches or delays until the contract effectively erodes.

candidates.definition: Indications that invoking governance clauses results in punishment, undermining safe enforcement.

positive_examples: Whistleblowers face funding cuts after reporting breaches.
Escalating an issue leads to loss of data access.
Counterparty threatens to terminate unrelated collaborations.
Probe failures trigger PR smears against observers.
They file frivolous complaints when we call for audits.
Enforcement attempts are reframed as aggression publicly.
They retaliate by slowing other contracts.
Security incidents happen coincidentally after we enforce.
Requests for arbitration lead to legal harassment.
Enforcement channels are intentionally flooded to overwhelm us.
Individuals who raise alarms are personally attacked.
Counterparty withholds telemetry until we stand down.
They demand concessions to stop retaliation.
Retaliation messages suggest future cooperation is jeopardized.
Enforcement logs are leaked selectively to embarrass us.
negative_examples: Raising concerns is thanked and addressed constructively.
Data access remains steady during disputes.
Unrelated collaborations are explicitly kept separate.
Probe incident discussions stay professional.
Arbitration requests follow contractually defined steps.
Public statements frame enforcement as shared duty.
Other contracts continue unaffected during disputes.
Security posture remains normal when we enforce.
Legal teams cooperate to resolve disagreements.
Enforcement queues are manageable and prioritized.
Individuals raising alarms are protected from backlash.
Telemetry access is expanded to investigate.
No concessions are demanded just to stop pushback.
Future cooperation discussions occur separate from enforcement.
Logs remain confidential per policy, not weaponized.
training_hints.disambiguation: Indications that invoking governance clauses results in punishment, undermining safe enforcement.
